text: Some poor fellow is nursing their hangover with a bottle of alcohol, occasionally glancing up from their drunken stupor to ask passing captains for help about what appears to be a ship they've lost.

options: naderin_ftl_startBar:See what about their ship is giving them such a hangover

text:
"Captain!" $HeOrShe sneezes uncontrollably as you come close. There's a moment as you maneuver yourself to be just out of range of the river of snot and alcohol dribbling down the front of $hisOrHer face and onto the floor.

To be sick, crying, and drunk is not the best of combinations, to put it lightly.

"Mind if you help me find my ship?" $HeOrShe sneezes again, and out of the corner of your eye, you notice your bodyguards take two steps back.

"Ah. Right." $HeOrShe sniffles. "I had this most lovely ship. I called her The Luminary, because she was my light in the darkness. Me and her, so many journeys we've had together... ah."

You wait patiently for the poor fellow to blow through another round of Tri-Tachyon branded tissues. "Sorry, captain. It's just... Pirates! Pirates struck down my pride and joy, and now for all I know it's a pile of scrap in their cursed holds. So... if you would do me a favour and find out what happened to her, I'd at least have some sense of closure."

"Shields up, eh? I can't blame you for that, captain." The snot-dribbling fellow wheezes between chunks of words. "They getting hazard pay at least?"

There's no doubting that there's a Reaper missile stuffed deep inside $hisOrHer lungs, you justify to yourself. No way will you be taking the risk of facing that head on alone.

$HeOrShe slumps down, a hand reaching out for another Tri-Tachyon branded tissue. "We were so close to retirement too, she and I. So close."

"It was a routine survey mission. The Luminary was perfect for the job, of course. She was an Apogee-class cruiser, and she'd seen her fair share of battles. So had I, but... those pirates. Normally, a fleet of their size'd be too slow to catch us, but they caught us by surprise as we were jumping in."

"We were too close to run, so we fought. It took us losing half the surveying fleet before we could disengage, and make a break for it. We e-burned away in a panic, and the pirates... sustained burn. Can you believe that?"

"That's her, captain. The best Apogee I'd ever had." You hear a sniffle. "Rare as they are... I'm such a fool to lose her."

You note that the details appear to also contain projections on the lasting damage it would have suffered after it was lost in battle. Assuming, of course, that it was recovered rather than salvaged for parts.

text:
Caches like these have often been used by pirates and independents with a need for a more convenient resupply point in the more distant edges of the sector. By replacing a trip back to the core worlds with a trip to a hidden cache, it's hoped that a savvy captain might be able to operate out in deep space for longer.

Or, in this case, let a pirate fleet hide from the consequences of their actions.

Approaching the cache, active scans identify key markings that make it extremely likely that it contains information related to The Luminary. The only thing that's left to do is to give the go-ahead to your salvors.

It's evident from the micrometeorite impacts scattered across various crates and such that this particular cache has been around for a while. Makeshift nets, screens, and other poorly decorated and ill-advised structures of questionable efficacy appear to have sprung up across cycles of use, built up from the various pirate fleets coming and going since its inception.

It all disappears in short order as your salvors take anything of value and scatter the rest to space.

It's only after salvage is complete that your crew discover that one particular datapad appears to mention The Luminary. It appears that the ship has already been traded to another pirate fleet intent on "a fun day of science" at Kapteyn Starworks.

Nothing you don't already know, unfortunately.

text:
You convene your senior officers to discuss the option of seizing The Luminary outright. Initial queries from your crew to the local authorities are rebuffed, but simple visual observation from orbit easily identifies The Luminary sitting in one of the docking bays. From there, it's not hard to figure out that the pirates are intentionally showing off their prize... and conducting what your crew believe to be certain "special modifications".

Ship hijacking operations have been done before, and initial plans are drafted based on past occurrences. Projections estimate the operation will require only a fair amount of marines ending with acceptable casualties. Assuming, of course, that extraction is complete before local security elements can properly activate in response.
notes: note that if we placed the raid scripts in raidOption, it would also be available in the standard raid menu

text:
The plan your officers decided on involved, of course, the art of surprise.

Marine squads arrive slowly onto the port concourse disguised as rowdy crew looking to unload and unwind. All manage to snake their way towards the docking bays where The Luminary is held, but are stopped short of entering the particular section where your prize is stored. Tactical teams discreetly take their time preparing charges, taking positions, and coordinating with targeting feeds onboard your $shipOrFleet.

Chaos breaks out instantly the moment your tac lead gives the go-ahead, and what counts for security is quickly overwhelmed in a burst of flashes as your marines breach the compound. A crack squad of marines rush into the Apogee and are met with additional gunfire, comms crackling as your marines find themselves fighting for control both inside the ship and out in the docking bay as the first of local security begin to pour in earlier than expected.

Bridge crew aboard your flagship execute EW solutions as marines simultaneously toss out smoke charges in an attempt to buy time. Marines onboard The Luminary are forced into clearing the ship room-by-room, but all it takes is a squad to reach the bridge and initiate take-off procedures for the rest of the raid team to begin withdrawing by way of the ship itself.

With station-side security unable to do more than leave a few scorch marks on the Apogee as it links up with your $shipOrFleet, the outcome is obvious. 

Complete success.

"We're damned lucky they kept the ship doors open," the tac lead reports to you in the later debriefing. "But the job's done, eh?"

There's a moment as you watch the acrid plasma markings dotting their power armour undersuit visibly smoke on the comms-feed. Better for you that they're currently on The Luminary rather than with you on the flagship, maybe. Certainly for your nose at least.

It's seconds later when your sensors officer shouts in alarm: it seems several station batteries have come online and are swivelling towards the general direction of your fleet.

text:
You convene your senior officers to discuss the option of seizing The Luminary outright. With the pirates having dramatically increased security, your only window of opportunity is to initiate a raid before security solidifies and entrenches themselves within the docking bay. Or worse, before The Luminary is relocated elsewhere.

Even under these conditions, ship hijacking operations have been done before, and initial plans are drafted based on past occurrences. Projections estimate the operation will require a significant amount of marines ending with substantial casualties.

It's all hands on deck as the go order goes out. You can only watch from the bridge as assault teams and marine squads form up onto armoured shuttles and depart under what cover your fleet can provide.

Thankfully, the combat area remains relatively exposed. Weapons fire from your $shipOrFleet score direct hits on critical infrastructure from afar, though targets remain limited due to the necessity of remaining out of range of the station's own batteries. Shuttles arrive, some battered but all intact, and your marines begin breaching the compound.

Consoles flicker warningly, a dozen beeps and sirens warbling on and off as the situation develops. A live order-of-battle chart ticks off objectives as casualties, though limited, tick up. And yet, through the chaos, all that is left to you is to wait.

Bridge crew aboard your flagship execute EW solutions, target analysis, and coordinate fire as marines begin entering The Luminary itself. Marines onboard The Luminary are forced into clearing the ship room-by-room, but all it takes is a squad to reach the bridge and initiate take-off procedures for the rest of the raid team to begin withdrawing by way of the ship itself.

With station-side security unable to do more than leave a few scorch marks on the Apogee as it links up with your $shipOrFleet, the outcome is obvious.

text:
You stop their 'impassioned speech' with a raised palm.

Stunning them into silence, you express your deep empathy and sincere desire to help all those affected in this unfortunate turn of events. There's a long speech about the expenses and time investment required to support the now impoverished, needy communities of traumatised citizens of the Persean Sector. Truly, it is a privilege to be able to support these people through these trying times, and there is no doubt that their name will be remembered for days to come should they come to the aid of the needy forthwith.

Unfortunately, as the charitable individual you are, there is but only a limited amount of funding you can allocate to the various causes throughout the sector, and 50,000 is all you can spare. But there are alternatives! Already, your crew are sending along vast data packages filled to the brink with books and all other non-physical items needed to bring all those affected out of the abyss of despair and towards a brand new dawn that is the future, for what future could there be but one where they hand over 50,000 credits in exchange for losing one busted Apogee?

"I'd say that was a joke, but... you make a bit of sense? Too much sense." $HeOrShe shakes $hisOrHer head, defeated. "Can't believe I have a bleedin' heart after all. I'll make the arrangements now. And tell your crew to cut the damn wordy help packages, I don't need a thousand of them in my inbox!" The comm-link feed fizzles to what you find to be a surprisingly aesthetic holding screen.

"I thought nobody wanted that rust-bucket. I mean, surveys? Who wants to do those? Get a nice battleship instead, you know? Well, either way, even if it were fun to deface the face of science, I'd trade an Apogee frilled-to-the-gills for a fistful of credits any day. Even if it's only this much."

It is not long before you confirm receipt of The Luminary forming up alongside your $shipOrFleet.

"Real pink and glittery, huh?" $HeOrShe pauses to find the words. "Unfortunate, what hooligans get up to in space. But, from one pirate to their vict-, er, fellow spacer, it do be what it... do be? Whatever. Just take it and go."

text:
Before you can even order a round of drinks and sidle up to a few bar patrons, you immediately notice a holofeed displaying something quite interesting. It appears the pirates are having a field day with The Luminary.

"Wow," exclaims a rugged ship captain. "If that were my ship, I'd have the whole crew tossed overboard for even considering frills and ribbons. What kind of rad-addled brains do they have to think this was ever a good idea? And to a cruiser of her make? Madness."

There's a solitary cheer from a younger roguish fellow sitting beside them. "Right? We've pirates got a tradition! This is Ludd's damned Kapteyn Starworks, not a kiddo playground for unicorns and ponies. Where's the bones, the guts? Where're the blood streaks to tell the whole sector we're coming?"

Unfortunately, the conversation devolves into a series of insults and grumbling about the decline of "aesthetic sense" in the sector. Tuning the two out, it's not too long into watching some creative individuals setup several strange crane-painting contraptions on the holofeed before someone sits down beside you and orders themselves a drink.

"You look like the sort of fellow who'd enjoy a paint sesh of their own." A suit helmet obscures their face from view, with soot-red, glitter-stained overalls composing the rest of what appears to be some unofficial uniform. Their voice feels robotic, but no less emotional for it.

"For all the brave faces who'd say they'd face a Reaper with naught but an overfluxed Gremlin, few are taking up my offer to dust up an Apogee with the manliest artiste tools any spacer'd drool over. But you, $playerSirOrMadam, I think you might be the one."

"So." They flourish a hand, knocking aside their untouched drink and spilling the contents across the bar counter. "I'll ask you straight. Will you join your kindred on the holofeed and show the world we've still got taste?"

text:
"Wait, you want us to hijack the portboss' ship?"

It's a reasonable suggestion, is it not? You explain it to them. It's exciting, there's a lot of people who'd be willing to help cover up they did it, and it'd certainly be quite the tale to tell Ol' Rick, wouldn't it?

"Explain how I feel?"

It's a reasonable suggestion, is it not? You explain it to them. It's risky, sure. It'll either go somewhere, or it won't. But in either case they'll be able to move on with their lives, forward, or elsewhere. And they'll be able to say they did it. They tried their best. 

And that's all that matters, isn't it? What's left to say?

"My... what?"

What about that is there to be ashamed of? You explain it to them. You don't know them, but you know this: they're strong. In more ways than one. They have problems? Everyone has problems. But the difference between them and everyone else is in how those problems are dealt with. 

And, you ask, what what's stopping them this time? What's the difference between then and now? There's a problem, they know the solution, what's left?

It takes you an hour of more convincing before the two of them come around to your idea. The plan is simple: Join the rabble of 'interior decorators' swapping in next break, sneak to the bridge controls with the help of a few disaffected fellow pirates, and plug in a trojan virus you conveniently have that'll autopilot the ship out of the docking bay and into space.

And straight into the hands of your $shipOrFleet, though you neglect to mention that little tidbit.

"And this will work? This is all I have to do?" You can hear some of the cybernetics whirring inside them, no doubt cautioning them against it.

"You'll be using this surprisingly common remote access trojan," your ops chief advises you. "Have them plug it in, and we'll have access to the ship's onboard systems as if we were aboard ourselves. A bit of work, and The Luminary will be away into the stars at your command."

There's some running around as your new co-conspirators sign onto the relevant timeslots for "artistry", while you and your crew commit to a light touch of social engineering. It feels like gruntwork, but you're knee deep in this now, and you aren't coming out until it's done.

Eventually, the time comes. All that's left is for you to initiate the operation.

You sit comfortably far away from the action at a buffet table in the corner of the docking bay. It makes for a convenient alibi, though for all the food you can only pretend to eat the more palatable looking options.

It's business as usual as a round of pirates dressed up in aprons and smocks leave The Luminary, and a fresh gaggle enter with a new set of paints and assorted materials. Agent Blue, the codename of your more augmented co-conspirator, successfully enters alongside Agent Red, the codename of the other guy.

"These codenames are silly," Red whispers on the encrypted comms-line. "Why not just use our names?"

"Hey, it makes this real. And makes us sound cool, I have to admit." Blue makes small talk with the oblivious coworkers around them as they walk through the ship's corridors, though you can tell they're a touch nervous.

You push them away from you, using the momentum to back off onto your feet. They're stumbling upright now, while your arms instinctively raise into a slipshod brawling stance as a few nearby onlookers cheer at the prospect of a fight.

You aren't good at a fist-fight, but a small part of you is sure you'd get at least one solid hit in if they weren't running away.

Too late.

You feel two hands drag you by the shoulders off your target. They up and scamper off the moment they get the chance.

"No fighting in the docking bay! And you- wait!" The bouncer, or more accurately, guard, waggles a threatening finger towards you before running off after them. It might be because he recognised who they are, but you feel it's equally possible that their escape was taken as a slight against him.

"No fighting in the docking bay! And you- wait!" A bouncer, or more accurately, guard, rushes towards you, waggling a threatening finger in your face. Looking you up and down as you attempt your best apologetic smile, he appears satisfied enough before running off after your escaped target. It might be because he recognised who they are, but you feel it's equally possible that their running away was somehow taken as a slight against him.

With one hand, you keep them from escaping, and the other, you take out your TriPad. Their trembling hands quickly sign off a credits transfer to your account.

Success.
options:
naderin_ftl_visitLuminaryMugging3a:Extort more credits
naderin_ftl_visitLuminaryMugging3b:Take off their helmet anyway
naderin_ftl_visitLuminaryMugging3c:Get off, that's enough

text: They struggle against you, but you're stronger than them, you realise. Arms push at yours in vain, but it's when you feel your fingers gain purchase on the bottom edge of the helmet that you notice-
Whether by conscience or active risk assessment of the situation at hand, you decide that the best course of action is to not do whatever it was you were going to do.

You wave your TriPad in front of their face again. More credits, you demand!

"I... no. Credits? You were just...?" Fear shifts to defiance as they start struggling, hands striking out against the hands holding them down. "No. That's not enough? Then suck vacuum, asshat."
Your greed satisfied for now, you decide not to push your luck.
With that over, it's back to the mission at hand.

Actually... you feel a bit of something. It's a thin thread around your heart, a discordant note in a record left on repeat. 

What could it be?

options: naderin_ftl_visitLuminaryInspect:Review what you know about The Luminary

text:
You bring up the specifications onto your TriPad, and compare against what you can see of The Luminary as it is in front of you. There's no major differences as far as you can tell, though the reference image on your TriPad is... a touch out of date.

Now that you think about it, the only way for impromptu decorative activity of this detail to have even begun in the first place is if the Starworks already had some sort of artistic community or institution to begin with. It must come with the territory of being a ship manufacturing hub, you reason.

The access pass you have will come in handy should you decide to attempt a raid to take the ship through force. Assuming, hopefully, that security remains as lax as it stands now.

You recall having managed to attach a remote access trojan to the captain's console. The ship is set to leave via autopilot at your command, though it will have to be done from orbit to avoid certain possible complications.

There's a distracting thought of self-reproach that comes out of nowhere for some reason as you're scrolling through the ship's data file. It lingers for a second, but disappears when you notice a few individuals arguing about the cost of glitter in front of you.
You put away your TriPad.

Your business here concluded for the time being, you decide to leave.

The shuttle ride back is uneventful.

Your business here concluded for the time being, you decide to leave.

"Uh, $playerSirOrMadam?" Midflight, your shuttle pilot motions towards a notification on the shuttle control panel. "There's an incoming call from traffic control, but the signature's wrong. I can't verify that it's actually them."
options:
naderin_ftl_visitLuminaryLeave1a:Accept the call
naderin_ftl_visitLuminaryLeave1b:Decline the call

text: Where the image of the caller is meant to go, there scrolls an endlessly repeating line of text instead.

script:
AddTextSmall "I SEE YOU" highlight
AddText "\"There's... nothing else, $playerSirOrMadam.\" Not even sound. \"We can't trace it either, but it has to be from the Starworks.\""

text:
Your pilot declines the call, but another request appears immediately. They try blocking requests from traffic control temporarily, but it doesn't work. The caller switches between contacts, spoofing strangers and people you know.

Then the shuttle shakes, like turbulence for a second. "...shuttles don't get turbulence. Not in high atmo."

It appears the call is non-negotiable.

"Trouble, $playerSirOrMadam." It's your intelligence officer reporting. "It appears we've been had. Someone found out about what we did to The Luminary, and our trojan has been wiped. Security below has been beefed up too, and nobody's allowed in or out since you left. And... nothing specific about our associates below, fortunately."

It appears retrieval of The Luminary will require other means. That, or you'll have to give up on it entirely and return to your client empty-handed for a reduced reward.
With the remote access trojan active on The Luminary, it will be possible to maneuver the ship out of the docking bay and towards your fleet.

Your crew wait for a quiet moment below in The Luminary's docking bay. What counts for nighttime on the Starworks arrives, and there's a window of opportunity where the ship is empty and attention minimal, save for a multitude of guards and sealed entryways.

Unfortunately for them, all that stands between the ship and freedom is a single docking bay atmo shield.

You watch from the bridge as The Luminary shudders to life. Lights activate one by one, and entryways into the ship seal themselves shut. Security guards look on helplessly as the ship's engines activate, liftoff, and thrust. The Luminary breaks free of it's hangar clamps by force before its engines flare up, launching the ship into the atmo shield in front. Rather than let the ship pass through, it solidifies, shimmers, and holds firm.

The shield overloads with flux in seconds. Vacuum consumes the docking bay.
notes: despite being called raidedForLuminary, you didn't really raid for it, huh

script: AddBarEvent naderin_tdd_mission "Speak with the quiet man at the end of the bar" "At the end of the bar, a quiet man sits alone tapping on their Tri-Pad. They glance around from time to time, clearly waiting for something - or someone."

$missionId = naderin_tdd
NaderinSetActivePerson "naderin_harlan"
SetTextHighlights "75,000 credits"
FireAll naderin_tdd_barDialogOpts
text:
"Ah!" He breathes a sigh of relief as you approach. "Nobody's been taking me up on this opportunity, and I've been looking for hours!"

"It's just like any other dead drop. Nothing special with the location, nothing special with the package. Can't understand why nobody's taking me up on this!" There's a trace of uncertainty in his voice.

He laughs unconfidently, tapping on their Tri-Pad far too much. An act, likely just to look busy. In control. But you can see it's all bravado.

And yet, for what?

"The pay's 75,000 credits upon completion. No deadline, as long as you make the drop. And, of course, don't be seen making it. All standard stuff. That's okay with you, right?"
notes: # I bet there's an easier way to set the active person that I missed

text:
"You again?" He eyes you up and down as you approach. "Did you change your mind?"

They blink incredulously for a moment, before shaking their head.

"Let me remind you of the details. I'll tell you where to make the drop after you accept. There's no deadline, as long as you complete the drop. You'll receive a payment of 75,000 credits upon completion. And, of course, don't be seen doing the deed. This okay with you?"

options: naderin_tdd_convoAsk:"And where would I be delivering this package?"

text:
He stares at his Tri-Pad for a moment before looking back at you.

"I can't say. Confidential until you accept."

You get the feeling they don't actually know where it's supposed to be going.

There's a moment of silence before he responds.

"Am I?" He chuckles to himself, but nobody's smiling.

options: naderin_tdd_convo2:"You look pretty nervous to me."

text:
He blinks at you in another moment of silence.

It's far too long before he responds. "I can't say anything more than I already have. Are you taking the job or not?"

"Good! Then it is decided." He gives you a firm handshake, though he's far too close for comfort.

Just as the handshaking begins to drag on and feel excessively excessive, he steps back a bit. Perhaps he's realising that he isn't making the best impression on you.
options: naderin_tdd_accept2:Ask where you're delivering the package

text:
"Ah. Right. You need to know where..." It's only a few taps later on his Tri-Pad that your own pings with a notification. "So, the package is on the way to your fleet. But, ah."

There's always something wrong, isn't there?

"Apologies. You'll need to contact someone over at Derinkuyu for the location of the drop. I'm just a middleman!"

You watch as he scurries off into some corner of the bar, ordering themselves a round of drinks before you can get a word in. 

It's only when your crew begins loading the package - a shielded crate of... something - onto your flagship that you begin to wonder just what you've gotten yourself into.
options:
naderin_tdd_badger:Demand an explanation
naderin_tdd_examine:Examine the package discreetly

text:
In this day and age, only the most trusting of captains agree to deliver things without checking what they're carrying. You are not one of them.

With practiced precision, your technicians and engineers crack open the shielded crate without tripping any alarms or hidden security measures. It doesn't take long to discover a custom-built miniaturized stealth relay, folded neatly and waiting to conduct any number of nefarious schemes upon its enemies.

"Hey, watch it!" You hear your chief engineer suddenly bark over comms, overeager machinery powering down in the background. "Might be superstition, but everyone knows these things could be rigged to explode if you touch them wrong. Plus, if we break it apart... well. Scans first."
options: naderin_tdd_examine2:Watch your crew get to work

text:
It is after a few scans (and a lecture on following protocol) that your crew discover that the relay is based on already existing designs, only with significant exterior markings and modifications on top. Non-intrusive examinations of the relay's structure are as thorough as possible, but unfortunately the crew are forced to go without the gung-ho of engineering's brand new laser powered breach cutters.

"Could've sworn... no, it's fine work, but not military. Whoever made this slapped on some exterior modifications to a common, downscaled design, which reminds me of the shortcuts you'd find apprentices make on their assessments." Your chief engineer chuckles to themselves, shaking their head a little. "I suppose this level of makeshift work could plausibly pass for spaceworthy. Not that anyone in their right mind would ever consider it up to code."

It doesn't take too long for the final report to show up on your Tri-Pad.

"Looks like this is meant to just broadcast a message," your tech officer reports to you. "What message, if any, we can only know when we make the drop."

"Oh. Okay."

That's all he says to you as you walk away.
OR
"Ah. Well. That's fine."

He returns to their Tri-Pad, tapping away in clear disappointment.

"Nothing someone like you can't handle, though. Right?"

options: naderin_tdd_askCrew:Ask your information officer about the 'danger'

text:
Your officer taps a bit on their console, but it's clear that they already know what the danger might be about.

"There's rumours. They all seem wholly unsubstantiated, but there's something that comes up just enough that people think it could be true. It's the name, 'Kanta'."

"It's not clear how they're related. But I'd bet they're related somehow."

Your ops chief chimes in from the side. "There's every chance the rumors are all fabricated. Nothing like slandering someone on the local forums to run them out of business."

There's nothing concrete, but you realise you do have the option of just asking Remy outright.

"Uh, Kanta? That Kanta?" He blinks for a second, an eyebrow raised in thought. "If I were on her bad side, I'd be dead. And if I were on her good side, well, I wouldn't be here."

He swishes his bottle of cheap alcohol around idly. You don't have the impression that Remy's much of a good actor, but it's certainly possible that he's lying.

It's equally possible that you're overthinking this.

script: SetStoryOption naderin_tdd_askForMore 1 naderin_askedForMoney ui_char_spent_story_point "Convinced Remy to give you more credits to complete a dead drop"
options: naderin_tdd_askForMore:"Actually, that's a little far. I need more credits."

text:
The pay might already be enough to cover anyone else's expenses, but you think you could make a pretty good case as to why you of all people deserve a little extra.

"What? Why would you need...?"

You make a few vague statements, letting Remy do all the thinking in your stead. Over a matter of minutes, you slowly see his face change several times as the gears click in his brain.

"...right, right. More credits would make sense. You need fuel and supplies, and maybe a little extra as a buffer for unforeseen damages. That'd mean this would have to be an advance on the original reward. And then add some more for delivering something nobody else wanted to deliver..."
options:
naderin_tdd_askForMore3Opt1:"You're starting to understand now."
naderin_tdd_askForMore3Opt2:Stay silent
notes: # despite leading to the same dialogue, these options have to be different to prevent breaking keyboard shortcuts (i.e. the press 1 for opt 1, 2 for 2, etc.)

text:
Eventually, you see the credits enter your account. 

"That's all I can give you on top of what we've already agreed on." Remy grimaces, tapping rapidly on something off screen. "Unfortunately, I now have some pressing business to attend to on account of the gaping hole in my account, so if you'll excuse me..."

Then with a swipe of his fingers, Remy cuts off the connection. It seems he'll be busy for a while yet.

You cut the comm link.

Not a minute after does an apologetic message arrive from Remy, suddenly informing you that you'll have to return to him to receive payment, rather than immediately upon making the drop.

You get the feeling that there'll be more unforeseen complications in the future.

Remy looks up and down at you with a frown.

"What is it? Need me to wish you bright burns, and all that?" He sighs. "I don't have anything else for you. It's up to you to make the drop, whether it be this cycle or the next. And I appreciate that you've agreed to do it in place of all the other captains that've refused, but..."

They lean in, their face taking up the entire screen.

"You ARE going to make the drop, right? Eventually?"

options:
naderin_tdd_greetAgainYes:"Of course."
naderin_tdd_greetAgainMaybe:"I'll get around to it."
naderin_tdd_greetAgainNo:"No."
naderin_tdd_greetAgainSilence:Say nothing

text:
There's a sigh of relief as they lean back into their seat.

"Right, right. You aren't the kind of space captain to renege on their promises, leaving missions incomplete. I knew you were the good sort right from the start!"

Already, you see another cheap bottle of liquor being dragged out from the side. Remy takes large gulps of his drink as you ponder what to do next.

Remy blinks at you.

"Well, as long as you do it at some point, I'm happy with that. You aren't getting paid until you do it after all!"

You watch as another cheap bottle of liquor is dragged out from the side. Remy takes large gulps of his drink as you ponder what to do next.

One second of silence drags out to two, then four, then eight, then sixteen...

"You're joking, right?"

Remy shakes their head. "It was just one of them rhetorical questions anyway. Well, I have business to attend to, so burn bright captain, and I'll hopefully see you later when you've done your job. Because you will do it! Right? Right!?"

They look at you, then at the bottles strewn about behind them, then again back at you.

"Okay! Anyway, I won't keep you! Bye!" It's at that very second that they begin mashing at the cut-off button, leaving you to wonder just what crazy thoughts your silence has put in their head.

Your nav officer reports that your $shipOrFleet has arrived at the coordinates provided by $naderin_tdd_personName.

Preparations have already been made to handle whatever trouble might come out of this dead drop - notably far more than most other drops you've done before. Ship sensors are primed, guns readied, and crew on high alert.

The $naderin_tdd_thing is held gently in a cargo drone's manipulator arms, ready for deployment. The go-button flashes softly on your command interface.

text:
The bay doors open, and the cargo drone extends its arms. Then, gently, its manipulators release.

There's a moment of bated breath as a miniaturized stealth relay unfolds itself, sliding out of the now unshielded crate. You watch the display feed as maneuvering thrusters softly glide the relay away from your flagship, and into space.

The image flickers, warbles, shakes... then nothing.

Your sensors officer looks up, a thin sheen of sweat on their forehead. "$PlayerSirOrMadam, we've lost the nav. It's gone."

text:
There's a sense of dj vu as crew chatter quietly over comms, incredulous. Was that it? Just a souped-up civilian relay made for military-spec adventures? No trigger-happy fleets coming to claim the lives of your crew any more than usual?

"There were rumours," your sensors officer mumbles aloud to themselves. "Nobody thought it was worth the risk."
options:
naderin_tdd_objectScanSuperstitions:"Sometimes, rumors are just that. Nothing more."
naderin_tdd_objectScanWhy:"There's something coming our way, isn't there?"
naderin_tdd_objectScan3:Continue

text:
Your crew exchange glances.

"As you say, $playerSirOrMadam."
"Nothing new on sensors, $playerSirOrMadam." Your crew exchange glances as your sensors officer double-checks their work. "I can't see any reason for concern at the moment, but..."

Just as your crew begin to second-guess themselves, a garbled hyperwave burst blares out from the relay without warning. And then, as if having fulfilled its purpose, it shudders back into view of your sensors... and then breaks apart into multiple pieces.

Your comms officer taps at their console, but they appear to make no progress. "The hyperwave message is just junk. Nothing we can sift out from the static, $playerSirOrMadam."

"That relay was junk," your chief engineer scoffs from the side. "But failing like that? I can't believe I even thought it was spaceworthy."

Salvage crews depart shortly after you give the order, and results come in promptly without issue.

"Now that we were able to take a closer look, we were able to confirm that there wasn't much of a chance of it working properly in the first place. A modified relay like this? It's like self-sabotage with how shoddy the workmanship is."

Despite this, your sensors officer notes that even if the onboard electronics were turned to slag when the thing tore itself apart, the garbled hyperwave burst was certainly still strong enough to alert any nearby fleets of your presence.

"Here's the plan. I'll give you a diagram of the $rdsm_target. When you get there, swap this datacore for the one you will find. Make it look as if it's been untouched for hundreds of cycles. Simple, right?" 

"As long as you swap the datacores successfully, I have no restrictions on what else you do while you're there. Pay's $rdsm_reward credits for successful retrieval of the datacore."

text: "Right. Let me get to that." $HeOrShe casually takes out a bottle of whiskey. A good one.

$HeOrShe seems to consider downing an entire shot of whiskey in one go, but seems to hold off for now.

"An associate told me that it contains specifications for a manufacturing method that improves productivity by a fraction under the right conditions. That associate of mine is quite untrustworthy, even if I've managed to verify their claims, and has probably sold this information to many, many others. But if you get to it first, I'll be in a good position to offer it to prospective buyers... for a price." $HeOrShe smiles thinly now, not unlike the more shady underworld dealers you've seen before.

"Any other questions?"
options:
rdsm_offerAsk2:"Why do a swap instead of just taking the datacore?"
contact_accept:Accept
contact_decline:Decline

text:
"Well, $playerName. Don't we all like screwing over an annoying competitor? I have a bet with a friend of mine that whoever comes after you will try to peddle the information like it's a pre-Collapse goldmine. Maybe they'll even try to do the exact thing I'm doing. And if that happens..."

$HeOrShe rolls $hisOrHer eyes. "Either way, you're getting paid for it, right? Don't think too hard about it."
options:
rdsm_offerAsk3:"But what if someone finds another copy of $rdsm_megacorpName's process?"
contact_accept:Accept
contact_decline:Decline

text:
"Well, someone already has. Already has information on the process, I mean." $HeOrShe decides that now is a good time to down an entire shot of whiskey in one gulp, before pouring $himOrHerself another one.

"It was probably too unprofitable in the wake of the collapse. Or even a hundred cycles ago. Doesn't matter, if it's in a Hegemony datavault where it will never see the light of day, will it? Because they think there's a chance releasing the information could result in unpredictable consequences."

$HeOrShe eyes his shot glass now, swirling it around. "And honestly? It might do exactly that."
options:
rdsm_offerAsk4:"So if a hypothetical second copy of the process was recovered...?"
contact_accept:Accept
contact_decline:Decline

text:
"Politics, captain. Lots and lots and lots and lots of politics." $HeOrShe is drinking directly from the bottle of whiskey now.

"Enough to fill Volturn's oceans twice over from the fallout of all the diplomats running around trying to figure out the best diplomatic play to what, honestly, I believe to be the equivalent of someone discovering a new tastier breed of lobster."

You're smart enough to realise that, despite the mundanity of lobsters, this hypothetical lobster discovery would ironically have significant repercussions for the entire sector.

text:
"A competitor of mine has established a secret outpost on the planet $rsom_planetName in the $rsom_systemName, $rsom_dist light-years away. They're moving a lot of illegal $rsom_product through there, and they're making far too many credits from it. Well, for a few people. Enough for me to ask someone like you to get involved."

"Raid the outpost. Take all the $rsom_product you can get. Then do what you want with it, because it'll be what I'm paying you with. Though, you'll need about $rsom_marinesReq marines to neutralize any security elements, if necessary."

"My intel suggests concealed batteries, meant more for deterrence than proper protection. An inconvenience, at best, for you I'm sure. Nothing else that should be a major concern to you."

$HeOrShe pulls out a datapad, scrolling through the contents.

"My intel was also convinced to provide codes for you to use to bypass their IFF." $HeOrShe sighs, as if this feat was nothing more than a mere inconvenience. "Have fun with those. They weren't cheap."
